ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a large understanding of Roman history from ~60BCE - ~400 CE.
I learned all about the roman empire
I developed a great understanding of the Roman Empire, its development and the various individuals and groups that were apart of it.
A comprehensive study of the Roman empire.
A broad understanding of the Roman Empire, analyzed from various aspects
I became a better interpreter of ancient sources through this course's extensive use of ancient texts and opinions in its material.

The History of the Roman Empire from Augustus to 476. In additional to factual narrative history we also discussed general concepts like the Roman economy, Roman slavery, Roman arena, women in Roman Empire, etc.

I learned about the history of the Roman Empire, from the formation of the Principate to "the fall" of Rome (and a bit beyond). Lectures in the first part of the term were chronological (and very emperor/regime-focused); our work in the second part of the semester focused on different facets of Roman society before we dove back into the chronological side.
A deep dive into the history of the Roman Empire--its politics, culture, economy, and ideas--from Augustus to 476 AD.

A pretty significant amount of factual information about the Roman Empire from Augustus through the fifth century. I feel like I learned more "actual history" (events, figures, trends, lived experiences) in this class than in any other class I've taken for the History major.
Greater understanding about Roman life and late Rome Empire rule.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Lenski was definitely a strength of the class. His lectures are informational and engaging, and he was very approachable.

The course's readings were interesting for the most part, but some were difficult to approach. The lectures were very informative and served to piece together and simplify the overarching themes of the week's readings. Discussion section was exceptionally helpful in understanding the readings and diving into them on a deeper level.
Many strengths, the only weakness is that the weekly section readings were far too long and unrealistic

I thought the course was great because of the flexibility, lecture length, and the helpfulness of TFs. Not having to attend live lecture was something that I could always fall back on if Im super busy for a week. 

Noel is an amazing professor, super helpful, understanding, engaging, and informative. 

I really enjoyed the course and cant think of anything more that would improve it.
The lectures were incredibly informative

This course has a very strong breadth of material due to the lengthy time period covered. One thing I think could be improved is the way the disjoint between the chronological lectures and topical lectures are covered. Many of the topical lectures feel somewhat removed from the shifting narrative of Roman history, and I think doing more to note temporal changes in individual topic lectures (urban/rural divide, gender, cults) would make them feel more embedded in the overall narrative, albeit still out of order to some extent, of course. One other thing: I wish there was a bit more feedback given.

Prof. Lenski has great expertise in Roman history and he's skilled at breaking down complex concepts. Lectures were entertaining and informative. Readings were also interesting, though we didn't always have the clearest evaluative framework for discussing the academic articles we read. Weekly FRQs reinforced the material at regular intervals and made studying for the midterm and final pretty easy.

Strengths: dynamic lecturer, recorded lectures during pandemic made it possible for me take this class, good section leader. 

Weaknesses: If possible, would have preferred the section size to have been lower.

The biggest strength is the clarity of the class's syllabus and presentation. Prof. Lenski really knows his stuff  if you take this class and keep up, you will know a lot about the Roman Empire by the end. 

I also really liked Prof. Lenski's decision to uncouple the readings for sections (mainly primary sources) from the secondary sources and chronological material from the lectures. It allowed us to cover more ground, and to interact with the subject on multiple levels at once.

I do question the pedagogical choice to have closed-book midterm and final exams for a remote lectureit felt like an unnecessary choice that disadvantaged students for maintaining academic integrity  though I can't deny that studying forced me to internalize a lot of the narrative history.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all succeeded
I thought that the ability to watch live or recorded lecture was really great.

This class responded very well to the pandemic. The PPT visuals were very strong, and I felt both the professor and my discussion section's TF were very available to chat. I don't think I have much to say besides that.

I really appreciated that the lectures were recorded! I also appreciate the flexibility of Prof. Lenski and the TAs; at a difficult point in the semester they both acknowledged that what was going on was not normal and gave us a bit of breathing room.
Zoom, N/A

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this class was a good place to approach ancient/classical history. I hadn't really had too much experience with ancient history prior to this class, but I felt the materials were well structured to introduce a student to this period. Overall it was a very interesting class, although some topics may have been less interesting than others. With only one paper over the course of the semester, and non-extensive readings, I'd recommend this as a humanities gut or as a general interest class.
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone thats been interested in learning more about Rome on a deeper level. Most people know about the empire on a basic level, but this course really helps develop the narrative and allows people to understand why it was so influential.
Yes! It was a great course!
Anybody looking to learn more about Roman history should 100% take this course. It is very in-depth and comprehensive
I would definitely recommend! Great course if you are interested if learning an introductory level Roman Empire history
As long as they have at least some interest in Roman history, yes.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone.
This course was a fantastic, thorough introduction to Roman history. I recommend it to anyone curious about ancient history or imperialism in general.
Yes, learn about the Romans!
It's a must-take if you're genuinely curious or passionate about Roman history. Otherwise, I don't think the class will do much for you.
Yes
Yes, Professor Lenski's class was well taught and structured.
